query: I'm 16 and help care for my mother who has MS in Cambridgeshire. This is affecting my schoolwork. Is there any support for young carers?

retrieved_documents.content:
who can help you. You can find information about them at www.care-
network.org.uk  
 
Alzheimer’s Society offer support to carers and people with dementia 
coming out of hospital. You can find out more at www.alzheimers.org.uk   
 
Support for carers  
Caring Together provide support to carers in Cambridgeshire. You can 
find out more on their website www.caringtogether.org/   
  
Making Space offer carer support service for those caring for someone with a mental health condition who is between 18 - 65 years old in 
Cambridgeshire. You can find out more on their website 
www.makingspace.co.uk/cambridgeshire- carer -support
  
  
Centre 33 provide support for young carers across Cambridgeshire. You can find out more on their website www.centre33.org.uk
  
  
Find out more in our information sheets for Cambridgeshire at Care and 
support information sheets . 
 
Equipment and Technology Enabled Care  
Many people use equipment to help them remain independent, safe, and 
well in their homes.

[Page 5]
5 | Cambridgeshire All Age Carers Strategy Easy Read | November  2023 
 Pictures  Words  
 Over the next three  years w e plan to  make all our 
services for carers better. 
 
We have set up working groups to help us to do 
this. 
 1. We would like to speak to  young carers.  
 We will be working with schools and other people who work with young carers.  
 
Young carers  are children and young people 
under the age of  18 who help care for somebody 
in their family who is ill or has a disability.   
 We would like to see all young carers  have a 
happy life and plan to have better services  to 
support them.  
  
 
 2. We need to make sure we are supporting  
parent carers.  
 Some parent carers are not aware of the help that 
is available to them.  
 
Parent carers  provide care and support to their 
children and young people with additional needs 
and disabilities .

[Page 5]
 
 
5 | Cambridgeshire County Council – If you need care and support when you leave hospital  - Easy Read | 
August 2024 
 Being a carer  
Pictures  Words  
 If you are a carer, you can get support from Caring 
Together.   
 
You can find out more on their website www.caringtogether.org
 
 
 
 If you are looking after someone with a mental health 
condition, Making Space can help you.  
 The person needs to be between the ages of 18 and 65. 
 You can find out more on their website  
www.makingspace.co.uk/cambridgeshire- carer -
support  
 Centre 33 provide support for young carers across 
Cambridgeshire and Peterborough.  
You can find out more on their website.  
www.centre33.org.uk

[Page 5]
 
 
5 | Cambridgeshire County Council – If you need care and support when you leave hospital  - Easy Read | 
August 2024

 You can find out more on their website

support  
 Centre 33 provide support for young carers across 
Cambridgeshire and Peterborough.  
You can find out more on their website.  
www.centre33.org.uk

[Page 16 - FINANCIAL/BUDGET INFORMATION]
Types of Young Carers
The experience of organisations working with young carers suggests that as a group you are most 
likely to primarily be caring for one or both of your parents (59%), most commonly your mother, followed by your siblings (36.5%). We know that 21.5% of young carers in Cambridgeshire and Peterborough currently care for more than 1 person, with more than half (54.6%) of all you who access the support service caring for someone with multiple conditions.
In the period August 2021 – July 2022, 838 young 
carers received a Young Carers Needs Assessment in Cambridgeshire and Peterborough. Of these, 28% fell into the high need tier, 40% in the mid-need tier and 32% in the low need tier.I don’t tell [my friends] because I feel like some people are going to start bullying me at school. One of my friends [also a young carer] spoke to people and then he got bullied
“
”
16
www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk

The Caring Together Carers directory gives easy access to support across Cambridgeshire, 
Peterborough and further afield, you can view their Carers Directory  online to find useful information 
and support including work, training, and education as well as emergency support, and a wealth of advice and information for carers
We know that there can be an impact upon carers work and life balance with 26.3% of you in 
Cambridgeshire and 19.7% of you in Peterborough telling us that you are not in employment owing to your caring responsibilities. 
CARER VOICE
In the recent ‘Experts by Experience’ survey 49% of respondents reported having 
received ‘information, advice and guidance’ however, only 11%  reported 
receiving ‘support with education, employment or training’
10

answer:
As a young carer in Cambridgeshire, you can access support through **Centre 33**, which provides assistance specifically for young carers like yourself. This support can help address the impact of your caring responsibilities on your schoolwork.

- **Centre 33** offers support services for young carers across Cambridgeshire. You can find more information and reach out to them via their website: [www.centre33.org.uk](http://www.centre33.org.uk).

- The **Cambridgeshire All Age Carers Strategy** emphasizes the importance of supporting young carers to ensure they have a happy life and access to better services. This includes working with schools and other organizations to provide necessary support.

- You might also consider a **Young Carers Needs Assessment**, which was provided to 838 young carers in Cambridgeshire and Peterborough between August 2021 and July 2022. This assessment can help identify the level of support you need.

For more detailed information and to explore the support available, you can visit the Cambridgeshire County Council's resources at [www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk](http://www.cambridgeshire.gov.uk).

test_metadata.prompt_template:
Please answer the following question about social care services in UK local authorities based only on the information in the provided documents.

Question: {query}

Context from relevant documents:
{context}

Instructions:
1. Provide a clear, direct answer that would help someone needing this information. If information isn't available, state: "The available documents don't provide specific information about [aspect]."

2. Synthesize information from ALL relevant documents to provide the most complete answer rather than analyzing documents individually.

3. Structure your response with:
   - A concise 1-2 sentence summary first
   - Relevant details organized in short, clear paragraphs
   - Bullet points for lists or step-by-step information
   - Bold text for key information the user should notice

4. For financial information:
   - Include exact figures, time periods, and what the funding covers
   - Present financial data clearly: "The adult social care budget is **£X million** for [time period]"

5. Always include practical next steps or resources:
   - Provide contact information, URLs, or application methods mentioned in the documents
   - Suggest where the person could find more information

6. When citing sources, use a simple format: "According to [document name/description]" or include URLs where available.

Answer:
